Subject: Re: [junit] Test Everything, No Matter How Simple
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=12653864; y=s99R9-X0ppKRNZLBYqJde042FXcI0Vy8dHXHplANmF3HexeZ

Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:
> On 8/22/06, Elliotte Harold <elharo@...> wrote:
>> Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:
>>
>>> So you're recommending 100% code coverage?
>>>
>> Yes.
> 
> 
> That's not very realistic, is it?
> 

Only in a binary world. In the real, fuzzy world it's not a yes or no, 
100% or 0%, situation. It's a case of more being better than less. You 
can asymptotically approach 100% coverage, even if you never quite get 
there.

Furthermore, it's not the "too to simple to fail" parts that are hard to 
test. What's hard to test are the really tricky bits, like whether the 
GUI is showing the right picture on the screen, whether the special case 
to work around a bug in one particular VM on one platform is working 
correctly, or what happens when a chunk of "unreachable" code is 
actually reached.

I'll be hosting a panel at SD Best Practices in Boston next month with 
Bob Martin and Scott Ambler to talk about precisely these sorts of 
things. By the way, I'm still looking for one more panelist for this so 
if anyone's interested, please drop me a private e-mail.

--
